A person shall not walk or exercise any animal on any property not owned by the person walking the animal, whether public or private, unless the owner has appropriate device or means for the collection of fecal material in his or her immediate possession and an appropriate container for the transportation of the fecal material for proper disposal. 
C.  A person shall maintain real property where an animal is harbored or maintained in a sanitary manner so that animals and humans are not harmed or affected by dangerous conditions, disease, odor, or vermin. 
D.  A person shall ensure that dog, cat, or animal food, urine or fecal material on the property where an animal is harbored or maintained does not threaten the health, safety, or welfare of others or constitute a nuisance to others due to unsightly conditions, odor, disease, or the attraction vermin. 
E.  All persons who own, manage, lease, rent, occupy, or control any dwelling, garage, outbuilding, or other structure shall be equally responsible for keeping each structure in a clean and habitable condition and shall take all necessary steps to prevent conditions detrimental to the public health, including, but not limited to, rotting food, garbage, trash, urine, fecal material, or unsanitary conditions which could lead to disease, odor, or vermin. 
(Ord. 05-04 § 1 (part), 2005) 
6.04.110 - Violations and penalties. 
A.  A violation of the city of Wixom animal control ordinance shall be deemed to be a civil infraction. In the event a determination of responsibility for a civil infraction under this chapter is made, a maximum fine of one hundred dollars may be imposed. 
B.  In addition to ordering the defendant responsible for a civil infraction to pay a civil fine, the court shall also impose any other costs, damages, and expenses as provided by law. 
C.  In addition to civil infraction enforcement, the court shall be authorized to issue any judgment, writ, order or equitable relief necessary to enforce, or enjoin violation of this chapter. 
D.  Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 05-04 § 1 (part), 2005) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.08 - GARBAGE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
Sections: 
Article II. - Installation and Maintenance of Refuse Containers 

8.08.100 - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all premises in the city which are served by collective refuse removal service in the form of collectively utilized refuse containers, within all residential, business, commercial, industrial, office and quasipublic zoning districts within the city. 
(Ord. 149 § 1, 1989) 
8.08.110 - Prohibited activities. 
    No persons owning, leasing, occupying or otherwise being responsible for the use of property in the city shall permit any of the following prohibited activities to occur: 
A.  Place or allow refuse to accumulate above and outside of a refuse container; 
B.  Permit hazardous materials, as defined by applicable city, state and federal law, to be deposited in the container; 
C.  Permit the container to serve as a habitat for vermin; 
D.  Permit contents of the refuse container to be dispersed by the wind or otherwise contribute to littering of the subject site or adjacent properties; 
E.  Place the refuse container within the public right-of-way or on the subject site so as to pose a vehicular or pedestrian traffic problem; 
F.  Fail to maintain the refuse container and/or the screening provided for the refuse container so as to pose any eyesore, detriment to the value of the subject and adjacent properties, public health concern or be contrary to the intent of this ordinance; 
G.  Use of wooden refuse containers. 
(Ord. 149 § 2, 1989) 
8.08.120 - Screening required. 
A.  To further address the public safety, health and welfare concerns outlined in Section 8.08.110 associated with the installation and maintenance of refuse containers, it is provided that all refuse containers located in the city subject to regulation under this article must be enclosed or screened from public view from anywhere on the subject site, with the exception of that side which may remain open pursuant to subsection (B) of this section. 
B.  Screening must be achieved to a height of not less than one foot above the height of the container, to completely conceal the contents from public view, but in no case shall the screening be less than five feet in height and on three sides. 
C.  Posts, bollards or bumpers shall also be provided to protect the screening from damage which may result from maintenance of the containers. 
D.  The inside dimensions of the enclosure must be adequate to permit access for refuse collection vehicles as well as completely enclose refuse bins within three sides so that no refuse container projects beyond the enclosure. 
E.  The requirement to screen refuse containers is not intended to apply to any refuse container which may be used on a temporary basis during the construction of any building, provided that the refuse container is removed from the premises prior to the issuance of a final certificate of occupancy for the building under construction. 
(Ord. 149 § 3, 1989) 
8.08.130 - Screening materials permitted. 
    To satisfy the requirements of this article, screening materials for refuse containers shall consist of the following, singly or in combination, and must be architecturally consistent with the materials utilized in the surrounding buildings: 
A.  Masonry, such as exterior wall brick or finished precast concrete block, such as striated or fluted block; unfinished cinder block not permitted; 
B.  Wood, provided that the wood is cedar, redwood, or marine grade exterior plywood or equivalent of at least five-eighths inch thickness or other types of wood pressure treated with preservatives. If cedar, redwood or plywood are used in the screening, it shall be protected from possible rot or decay by the application of a preservative on a regular basis by the owner, occupant or person otherwise responsible for the maintenance of the subject premises. The appearance of the wood screen cannot be permitted by the owner or their agent responsible for maintenance to deteriorate over time to the point of causing an eyesore or diminishing the effect of the screen which was achieved in the original installation; 
C.  Evergreen shrubbery consisting of permanent, living materials which shall be continuously maintained in a sound, health and vigorous condition, free of plant diseases, insect pests, weeds, refuse and debris. The shrubbery shall be maintained so as to create a continuous barrier, at the height specifications provided in this article; 
D.  Earthen berm or recession within an embankment so as to achieve a continuous barrier. 
(Ord. 149 § 4, 1989) 
8.08.140 - Enforcement. 
A.  The building official, code official or his or her designee are authorized to enforce the provisions of this article. 
B.  The enforcement duties authorized by this article include, among others, the following: 
1.  Investigation of ordinance violations; 
2.  Serving notices of violations; 
3.  Serving appearance tickets as authorized under Chapter IV of Public Act 175 of 1927, as amended, and Public Act 366 of 1984; 
4.  Appearance in court of other judicial proceedings to assist in the prosecution of ordinance violators; and 
5.  Such other ordinance enforcement duties as may be designated by the city manager. 
(Ord. 149 § 5, 1989) 
8.08.150 - Appeals. 
A.  The zoning board of appeals, as constituted under Ordinance 34, the zoning ordinance, shall serve as the appeal body for all provisions of this article and may, upon written application, consider appeals for waivers to the requirements of the ordinance governing the maintenance and enclosure of refuse containers. 
B.  The board may consider granting a waiver upon finding that strict application of the provisions of this article would result in practical difficulties or undue hardship to the landowner, lessee or occupant of the subject premises. In granting the waiver, the board may impose reasonable conditions in fulfillment of the spirit and intent of this article. 
C.  All meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman of the board. 
D.  The meetings of the board and any public hearing that may be called by the board shall be at reasonable times and places to accommodate the attendance of the petitioners and members of the general public. 
(Ord. 149 § 6, 1989) 
8.08.160 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars or imprisoned for a period not to exceed ninety days or both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 149 § 7, 1989) 
Chapter 8.12 - HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Short title. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the city's Hazardous Chemicals Ordinance. 
(Ord. 146 § 1.01, 1989) 
8.12.020 - Findings-Purpose. 
    The city council finds as follows: 
A.  There are certain commercial enterprises currently operating in the city, and there is a potential for the development of future business, industry, research and testing enterprises that engage in the handling, storage, use, processing, and disposal of hazardous chemicals. 
B.  The public health, safety and welfare of the citizens may be endangered by the improper handling, storage, use, processing, and disposal of such hazardous chemicals. 
C.  The surface waters, groundwater and soils within the city are particularly susceptible to damage from the improper handling, storage, use, processing, and disposal of hazardous chemicals. Moreover, the expense and difficulty of cleaning up surface water, groundwater and soils that have been damaged by hazardous chemicals makes it imperative that protective measures be taken to limit the threat of damage from such chemicals. 
D.  Article IV, Section 52 of the constitution of the state provides that the conservation and development of the natural resources of the state is of paramount public concern in the interest of the health, safety and general welfare of the people. 
E.  The health, safety and welfare of the fire, police and other emergency service personnel have in the past, and may in the future, be endangered because of a lack of complete knowledge of the types and locations of such hazardous chemicals. 
F.  Protection for the community is best advanced by regulation that is enforced with a spirit of mutual cooperation between the government and business entities, so that compliance will be achieved. 
(Ord. 146 § 2.01, 1989) 
8.12.030 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions apply: 
    "Carcinogen" means a chemical (a) regulated by OSHA as a carcinogen; or (b) that has been evaluated by the International Agency for Research on Cancer and found to be a carcinogen or potential carcinogen; or (c) that is listed as a carcinogen or potential carcinogen in the Annual Report on Carcinogens published by the National Toxicology Program. 
    "Chemical" means any element, chemical compound or mixture of elements and/or compounds. 
    "Combustible liquid" means any liquid having a flashpoint at or above one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (37.8° C), but below two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (93.3° C), except any mixture having components with flashpoints of two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (93.3°C) or higher, the total volume of which make up ninety-nine percent or more of the total volume of the mixture. 
    "Compressed gas" means (a) a gas or mixture of gases having, in a container, an absolute pressure exceeding forty psi at seventy degrees Fahrenheit (21.1°C); or (b) a gas or mixture of gases having, in a container, an absolute pressure exceeding one hundred four psi at one hundred thirty degrees Fahrenheit (54.4°C) regardless of the pressure at seventy degrees Fahrenheit (21.1°C); or (c) a liquid having a vapor pressure exceeding forty psi at one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (37.8°C) as determined by ASTM D-323-72. 
    "Critical Materials Register" means the Critical Materials Register promulgated by the Toxic Chemical Evaluation Section of the Environmental Services Division of the Michigan Department of Natural Resources, as the same may be updated from time to time. 
    "Employer" means an individual or organization which employs one or more persons. 
    "Explosive" means a chemical that causes a sudden, almost instantaneous release of pressure, gas and heat when subjected to sudden shock, pressure or high temperature. 
    "Fire chief" means the fire chief of the city or such other person as he may designate to act under the provisions of this chapter. 
    "Flammable" means a chemical that falls into one of the following categories: 
1.  "Aerosol, flammable," means an aerosol that, when tested by the method described in 16 CFR 1500.45, yields a flame projection exceeding eighteen inches at full valve opening, or a flashback (a flame extending back to the valve) at any degree of valve opening. 
2.  "Gas, flammable," means (a) a gas that, at ambient temperature and pressure, forms a flammable mixture with air at a concentration of thirteen percent by volume or less; or (b) a gas that, at ambient temperature and pressure, forms a range of flammable mixtures with air wider than twelve percent by volume, regardless of the lower limit. 
3.  "Liquid, flammable," means any liquid having a flashpoint below one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (37.8°C), except any mixture having components with flashpoints of one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (37.8°C) or higher, the total of which make up ninety-nine percent or more of the total volume of the mixture. 
4.  "Solid, flammable," means a solid, other than a blasting agent or explosive as defined in 29 CFR 1910.109(a), that is liable to cause fire through friction, absorption of moisture, spontaneous chemical change, or retained heat from manufacturing or processing, or which can be ignited readily and, when ignited, burns so vigorously and persistently as to create a serious hazard. A chemical shall be considered to be a flammable solid if, when tested by the method described in 16 CFR 1500.44, it ignites and burns with a self-sustained flame at a rate greater than one-tenth of an inch per second along its major axis. 
    "Flashpoint" means the minimum temperature at which a liquid gives off a vapor in sufficient concentration to ignite when tested as follows: 
1.  Tagliabue Closed Tester (see American National Standard Method of Test for Flash Point by Tag Closed Tester, Z11.24-1979 (ASTM D 56-79)) for liquids with a viscosity of less than forty-five Saybolt Universal Seconds (SUS) at one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (37.8°C), that do not contain suspended solids and do not have a tendency to form a surface film under test; 
2.  Pensky-Martens Closed Tester (See American National Standard method of Test for Flash Point by Pensky-Martens Closed Tester, Z11.7-1979 (ASTM D 93-79)) for liquids with a viscosity equal to or greater than forty-five SUS at one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (37.8°C), or that contain suspended solids, or that have a tendency to form a surface film under test; 
3.  Setaflash Closed Tester (See American National Standard Method of Test for Flash Point by Setaflash Closed Tester (ASTM D 3278-78)). 
    Organic peroxides, which undergo auto-accelerating thermal decomposition, are excluded from any of the flashpoint determination methods specified above. 
    "Hazardous chemical" means any chemical or waste which is a physical hazard or health hazard. 
    "Health hazard" means a chemical or waste for which there is statistically significant evidence, based on at least one study conducted in accordance with established scientific principles, that acute or chronic health effects may occur in exposed persons. The term "health hazard" includes chemicals which are carcinogens, toxic or highly toxic agents, reproductive toxins, irritants, corrosives, sensitizers, hepatotoxins, nephrotoxins, neurotoxins, agents which act on the hematopoietic system, and agents which damage the lungs, skin, eyes, or mucous membranes. 
    Further definition and explanation of the scope of health hazards covered by this chapter are to be found in Appendix A to 29 CFR 1910.1200, which is incorporated in this chapter by reference. 
    The criteria to be used to determine whether or not a chemical is to be considered hazardous are further described in Appendix B to 29 CFR 1910.1200, which is incorporated in this chapter by reference. 
    "Highly toxic material" means a material so toxic to man as to afford an unusual hazard to life and health during fire fighting operations. Examples are parathion, TEPP (tetraethyl phosphate), HETP (hexaethyl tetraphosphate), and similar insecticides and pesticides. 
    "Mixture" means any combination of two or more chemicals if the combination is not, in whole or in part, the result of a chemical reaction. 
    "Organic peroxide" means an organic compound that contains the bivalent -O-O structure and which may be considered to be a structural derivative of hydrogen peroxide where one or both of the hydrogen atoms has been replaced by organic radical. 
    "Oxidizer" means a chemical other than a blasting agent or explosive as defined in 29 CFR 1910.109(a), that initiates or promotes combustion in other materials, thereby causing fire either of itself or through the release of oxygen or other gases. 
    "Physical hazard" means a chemical or waste for which there is scientifically valid evidence that it is a combustible liquid, a compressed gas, explosive, flammable, an organic peroxide, an oxidizer, pyrophoric, unstable (reactive) or water-reactive. 
    "Poison A" means poison gas or liquid of such nature that a very small amount of the gas, or vapor of the liquid is dangerous to life. 
    "Radioactive material" means any material that spontaneously emits ionizing radiation. 
    "Use area" means any area where hazardous chemicals are utilized, treated or processed. 
(Ord. 146 § 3.01, 1989) 
8.12.040 - Pollution, impairment or destruction of natural resources. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other legal entity to cause or permit the pollution, impairment or destruction of air, ground waters, surface waters, soils or other natural resources in the city. 
(Ord. 146 § 4.01 (part), 1989) 
8.12.050 - Permits required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other legal entity to operate nay business or conduct any activity requiring a permit or other approval under any of the following statues, without first having obtained such permit: 
A.  The Hazardous Waste Management Act, Act 64 of the Public Acts of 1979, as amended, MCL 299.501, et seq.; MSA 13.30(1), et seq. 
B.  The Solid Waste Management Act, Act 641 of the Public Acts of 1978, as amended, MCL 299.401, et seq.; MSA 13.29(1), et seq. 
C.  The Water Resources Act, Act 245 of the Public Acts of 1929, as amended, MCL 323.1, et seq.; MSA 3.521, et seq. 
D.  The Liquid Industrial Waste Act, Act 136 of the Public Acts of 1969, as amended, MCL 323.271, et seq.; MSA 3.533(101), et seq. 
E.  The Underground Storage Tank Act, Act 423 of the Public Acts of 1985, as amended, MCL 299.701, et seq.; MSA 13.29(71), et seq. 
F.  The Air Pollution Act, Act 348 of the Public Acts of 1965, as amended, MCL 336.11, et seq.; MSA 14.58(1). 
G.  The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, as amended, 42 USC § 6901, et seq. 
H.  The Clean Air Act, as amended, 42 USC § 7401, et seq. 
I.  The Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC § 1151, et seq. 
J.  The Safe Drinking Water Act, as amended, 42 USC § 300f, et seq. 
(Ord. 146 § 4.01 (part), 1989) 
8.12.060 - Hazardous chemicals survey- Required. 
A.  The fire chief shall promulgate and make available a hazardous chemicals survey form to be utilized in accordance with this section. 
B.  All developers of property, all businesses or all employers shall complete and file with the city a hazardous chemical survey: 
1.  Upon submission of a preliminary site plan for the development of any property within the city; 
2.  With the filing of any business license form required by the city; 
3.  Upon any change of use or occupancy of a structure or premises within the city; 
4.  Upon request of the fire chief pursuant to Section 8.12.070. 
(Ord. 146 § 7.01, 1989) 
8.12.070 - Hazardous chemicals survey- Material safety data sheets. 
    Upon written request of the fire chief, an employer within the city shall, within ten working days, provide a completed hazardous chemical survey to the fire chief, and for hazardous chemical quantities meeting or exceeding the threshold requirements stated in Section 8.12.140, shall provide the list required to be prepared pursuant to 29 CFR 1910.1200, Section 14a, of the Michigan Occupational Safety and Health Act, MCL 408.1014a; MSA 17.50(14a), and Section 5p of Act 207 of the Public Acts of 1941, as amended, MCL 29.5p; MSA 4.559 (5p), and, when requested, a material safety data sheet for each hazardous chemical identified on the list. 
(Ord. 146 § 5.01, 1989) 
8.12.080 - Quantity and location of hazardous chemicals. 
    Upon written request of the fire chief, an employer within the city shall, within ten working days, provide a description of the quantity and location (by floor plan or diagram) of any hazardous chemicals specified by the fire chief after review of the lists provided under Section 8.12.070. Reporting of quantities shall include the maximum quantities expected at any given time. Upon request, the fire chief may extend the period for providing the information described in this section by an additional five working days. The requirement for this information may be satisfied in conjunction with the filing of the completed hazardous chemicals survey as provided in Section 8.12.060. Pursuant to Section 5p of the Michigan Fire Prevention Code, MCL 29.5p, MSA 4.559(5p), information obtained by the fire chief under Sections 8.12.070 and 8.12.080 of this chapter may be made available to a public official, agency or employee, but is exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act, as amended, MCL 15.231, et seq.; MSA 4.180 (1), et seq. 
(Ord. 146 § 6.01, 1989) 
8.12.090 - Updating of information. 
    A person subject to Sections 8.12.060, 8.12.070 and 8.12.080 shall provide the fire chief a written update of the information required by those sections when there is a change in the quantity, location or presence of hazardous chemicals in the workplace, or any other of the information required to be transmitted under those sections. 
(Ord. 146 § 8.01, 1989) 
8.12.100 - Outdoor storage. 
    The outdoor storage of hazardous chemicals is prohibited except in product-tight containers, recognized and accepted in accordance with federal and state standards, which are protected from weather, leakage, accidental damage and vandalism. No outdoor storage shall be permitted in violation of the city Zoning Ordinance. No indoor storage shall be permitted in violation of the state Construction Code or the city Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. 146 § 9.01, 1989) 
8.12.110 - Containment of storage or use areas. 
A.  All storage or use areas for hazardous chemicals where the quantities meet or exceed the threshold amounts listed in Section 8.12.140 shall be paved, diked, curbed, structurally enclosed or otherwise protected by spill control measures or mechanisms that are sufficient to prevent the release into the surface waters, groundwaters and soils. Secondary containment shall be by a method to be sufficient to safely contain any hazardous chemical which may escape from its primary container, in accordance with federal and state standards for secondary containment. When necessary for review of proposed methods of secondary containment, the fire chief may utilize the services of environmental or engineering consultants. The area shall be so constructed that no liquid polluting material can escape therefrom by gravity through building sewers, drains, other otherwise directly or indirectly into any sewer system, storm drainage system or the surface waters, groundwaters or soils of the city. Secondary containment shall not be mandated for flammable and nonflammable gases. 
B.  A secondary containment method expressly approved by the Water Resources Commission or its designated representative pursuant to Act 245 of the Public Acts of 1929, as amended, MCL 323.1, et seq., MSA 3.521, et seq., and the rules promulgated thereunder, shall be deemed to comply with the provisions of this section. 
C.  All secondary containment shall be continuously maintained so as to guarantee the containment of all polluting material. 
(Ord. 146 § 10.01, 1989) 
8.12.120 - Pollution incident prevention plan (PIPP). 
A.  No employer shall use, handle or store a hazardous chemical in quantities which meet or exceed the threshold amounts listed in Section 8.12.140 without having first filed with the city and having had approved by the fire chief a pollution incident prevention plan (PIPP). The PIPP shall be in a form as provided by the city and shall set forth: 
1.  The procedures by which such entity proposes to prevent pollution of the surface waters, groundwaters and soils of the city from storage and use areas, manufacturing, processes, treatment systems, shipping, and disposal of the hazardous chemicals; 
2.  The emergency clean-up procedures to be used in case of a spill, discharge, seepage, runoff, or leakage of any hazardous chemicals in the surface waters, groundwaters or soils of the city; 
3.  The type of surveillance employed by such entity; 
4.  The method by which inventories are made of hazardous chemicals from the time such chemicals are received or manufactured until such time as they are treated and discharged or otherwise disposed by the facility. 
B.  An updated PIPP shall be filed for review and approval by the fire chief whenever there is a change in the use, handling or storage of any hazardous chemicals. When necessary for the review of any PIPP, the fire chief may utilize the services of environmental or engineering consultants. 
C.  A PIPP expressly approved by the Water Resources Commission or its designated representative pursuant to Act 245 of the Public Acts of 1929, as amended, MCL 323.1, et seq., MSA 3.521 et seq., and the rules promulgated thereunder shall be deemed to comply with the requirements of this section. 
D.  Approved pollution incident prevention plans shall be followed at all times, including in the event of any spill, discharge, seepage, runoff, or leakage of any hazardous chemicals. 
(Ord. 146 § 11.01, 1989) 
8.12.130 - Secondary containment and PIPP approvals-Notice to adjacent property owners. 
    Prior to approval of a secondary containment system or PIPP, the fire chief (or city administration acting on behalf of the fire chief) shall mail notice of the request to those persons to whom real property adjacent to the proposed activity is assessed. The notice shall state that the application may be examined and shall indicate a date (not later then ten business days after receipt by the city of the application) prior to which written comments regarding the request may be submitted to the city for consideration by the fire chief. 
(Ord. 146 § 12.01, 1989) 
8.12.140 - Hazardous chemical thresholds. 
A.  The requirements for submission of the hazardous chemical list shall apply where the aggregate quantity of any given hazardous chemical meets or exceeds the state and federal thresholds for regulation, adopted by the city council by resolution. 
Chemical Type 
    Poison A 
    Highly toxic material 
    Explosives and blasting agents (including Class C explosives) 
    Radioactive material (Yellow III label) 
    Carcinogens 
    Other hazardous chemicals 
Material safety data sheets shall be provided as requested by the fire chief. 
B.  The requirements for providing secondary containment shall apply where the aggregate quantity of the given hazardous chemical meets or exceeds the quantities listed below: 
1.  Nonuse (storage) areas: 
a.  100 kilograms for hazardous chemicals listed on the Critical Materials Register; 
b.  1,000 kilograms for all other hazardous chemicals; 
2.  Use area: 
a.  227 kilograms (or 60 gallons) for hazardous chemicals listed on the Critical Materials Register; 
b.  1,000 kilograms for all other hazardous chemicals. 
C.  The requirements for providing pollution incident prevention plans (Section 8.12.120) shall apply where the aggregate quantity of any given hazardous chemical meets or exceeds one thousand kilograms, or in the case of gases, seven thousand cubic feet. 
D.  Hazardous chemical lists, secondary containment and pollution incident prevention plans shall not be required for quantities of hazardous chemicals consisting only of regular and experimental motor vehicle fuel contained within motor vehicles. 
(Ord. 146 § 13.01, 1989) 
8.12.150 - Inspections-Right of entry-Lock boxes. 
A.  The fire chief and building official shall inspect all structures and premises utilized by employers as often as may be necessary for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of the information provided under this chapter and ascertaining whether there exist any violations of this chapter or any other federal or state statutes, rules or regulations, or local ordinances relating to the use, storage, handling or disposal of hazardous chemicals. The inspections shall be coordinated to the extent practical with inspections conducted under the Business License Ordinance of the city. 
B.  Whenever necessary for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, or whenever the fire chief or building official have reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any structure or upon any premises, any condition which would constitute a violation of this chapter or any other federal or state statutes, rules or regulations, or local ordinances relating to the use, storage, handling or disposal or hazardous chemicals, the fire chief or building official may enter such structure or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the city official by this chapter, provided that if such structure or premises be occupied, the city official shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such entry is refused, the city official shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry, including the obtaining of a search warrant. 
C.  In those cases where the fire chief or building official observes or otherwise discovers violations of federal or state statutes, rules or regulations relating to the use storage, handling or disposal of hazardous chemicals, such violations shall be reported to the appropriate federal or state agency authorized to enforce such statute, rule or regulations. In addition, the fire chief or building official may request the city attorney, upon proper authorization, to commence proceedings pursuant to Section 8.12.160 of this chapter. 
D.  Inspections conducted pursuant to subsections (A) and (B) of this section may include the taking of samples of groundwater, surface water, soil or other substances for testing. Where such inspections or sampling reveal or confirm the violation of this chapter or any other ordinance or code provision of the city, or the violation of any state or federal statute, the cost of such sampling and related tests shall be assessed to the owner of the business of property involved. The relevant company may also take split samples. In the event such costs are not paid within thirty days of notice to the owner, the costs shall be assessed as a lien against the property which may be enforced as a delinquent city property tax. 
E.  Where the fire chief determines it is necessary for purposes of safe and efficient response to potential fire emergencies, the fire chief shall require a business to provide at its premises an accessible lock box for the storage of all material safety data sheets, pollution incident prevention plans and hazardous chemical surveys. The lock box shall be installed at a location approved by the fire chief, and shall be equipped with a lock operable by a master key system approved by the fire chief. 
F.  The ordinance enforcement duties authorized in this chapter shall include, among others, the following: 
1.  Investigation of ordinance violations; 
2.  Serving notices of violations; 
3.  Serving appearance tickets as authorized under Chapter IV of Public Act 175 of 1927, as amended, and Public Act 366 of 1984; 
4.  Appearance in court or other judicial proceedings to assist in the prosecution of ordinance violators; and 
5.  Such other ordinance enforcement duties as may be designated by the city manager. 
(Ord. 146 § 14.01, 1989) 
8.12.160 - Enforcement-Penalties. 
A.  Any person, firm, corporation or other legal entity violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction therefor shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars for each such conviction, or shall be punished by imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety days for each offense, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court, together with the costs of such prosecution. Each day upon which such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. 
B.  Any use or activity in violation of the terms of this chapter is declared to be a nuisance per se, and may be abated by order of any court of competent jurisdiction. The city council, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceeding to prevent, abate or restrain the violation. All costs, fees and expenses in connection with such action shall be assessed as damages against the violation. 
C.  In the event of a violation of this chapter that results in damage to the surface waters, groundwater, or soils within the city, the city shall have the power to order complete clean-up and restoration of the area involved by the person or agent responsible for the violation. If such responsible person or agent does not complete such restoration within the time specified in the order, the city shall have the authority to clean up and restore the affected area to the prior condition wherever possible; and the person or agent responsible for the original violation shall be held liable to the city for the cost of restoration. 
D.  In addition to remedies provided in subsections (A), (B) and (C) of this section, the city may maintain an action for declaratory or equitable relief against the state, any political subdivision thereof, any person, partnership, corporation, association, organization or other legal entity for the protection of the air, water and other natural resources and the public trust therein from pollution, impairment or destruction, including those instances where the air, water and other natural resources are threatened by violations of federal or state statutes, rules or regulations relating to the use, storage or handling of hazardous chemicals. In such action, a prima facie case for relief shall be made by a showing that the conduct of the defendant has, or is likely to pollute, impair or destroy the air, water or other natural resources or the public trust therein. The defendant may show, by way of affirmative defense, that there is no feasible and prudent alternative to its conduct and that such conduct is consistent with the promotion of the public health, safety and welfare in light of the state's paramount concern for the protection of natural resources from pollution, impairment or destruction. 
(Ord. 146 § 15.01, 1989) 
8.12.170 - Appeals-Variances. 
A.  The hazardous chemicals appeals board shall have jurisdiction over appeals and variances as provided in this chapter. The hazardous chemicals appeal board shall consist of three members, appointed by city council, employed or trained in one of the following occupations: biochemist, biologist, chemist, chemical engineer, civil engineer, environmental engineer, environmental scientist, geochemist, hydrologist, hydrologic engineer, industrial hygienist, industrial chemist, occupational safety engineer, physician, soils engineer, water quality specialist, or such occupation, similar experience, education and expertise as the above. The membership of the board shall include at least one person, but not more than two persons, representing business interests within the city. Board members shall be resident of the city or, in the case of a member representing business interest, be employed by an entity conducting business at a location within the city. The members of the hazardous chemicals appeal board shall generally serve for a three-year term. However, the initial board shall consist of one member appointed for a one-year term, one member appointed for a two-year term, and one member appointed for a three-year term. 
B.  The hazardous chemicals appeal board shall hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by the applicant that there is an error in a determination by the city fire chief or building official to deny approval of a proposed method of secondary containment or a proposed PIPP. A claim of appeal to the hazardous chemicals appeal board shall be filed with the city clerk within twenty days of the date of such denial. The hazardous chemicals appeals board shall conduct a de novo review of the determination of the fire chief and determine whether it shall be affirmed or modified. 
C.  The hazardous chemicals appeals board may authorize, upon an appeal, a variance from the strict application of the provisions of this chapter where such strict application would result in practical difficulties or undue hardship, where such relief may be granted without substantial detriment to the public good and without substantially impairing the intent and purpose of this chapter. In granting a variance the hazardous chemicals appeal board may attach thereto such conditions as it may deem reasonable in furtherance of the purpose of this chapter. The relief granted shall in no instance be greater than necessary to relieve the practical difficulty or undue hardship. 
(Ord. 146 § 16.01, 1989) 
8.12.180 - Grace period. 
    The requirements for secondary containment (Section 8.12.110) and pollution incident prevention plans (Section 8.12.120) shall be effective ninety days after the original adoption of this chapter. However, where the fire chief or building official determines that there is otherwise an imminent danger to the surface waters, groundwater or soils of the city, immediate compliance shall be required to those sections. In such instances, the fire chief or building official shall notify the owner or occupant of the property in writing that immediate compliance is mandated. No appeal to the hazardous chemicals appeals board shall be permitted under Section 8.12.170 from a determination by the fire chief that there is an imminent danger to surface waters, groundwater or soils which requires immediate compliance with the requirements for secondary containment or PIPP preparation. 
(Ord. 146 § 17.01, 1989) 
Chapter 8.16 - LANDFILLS 
Sections: 
Article I. - In General 

8.16.010 - Scope-Intent. 
A.  The regulations in this chapter apply to all filling of land within the city by the deposition of materials originating off the premises on which the fill is located. They cover the review of proposed fill sites, information to be supplied with applications for landfill permits, fees for review of applications and plans, inspection charges, deposits to ensure payment of inspection charges and compliance with regulations and conditions of permits, design of landfills, operations and equipment. 
B.  It is intended to regulate the location, design, materials and operation of landfills so that no landfill shall be a nuisance, nor cause any damage to surrounding property, nor endanger the health or safety of the community. 
(Ord. 85 §§ 1.0, 2.0, 1971) 
8.16.020 - Building official-Defined. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, "building official" is defined as the building official for the city of Wixom. 
(Ord. 85 § 3.0, 1971) 
Article II. - Application for Permit 

8.16.030 - Exceptions-Permits not required. 
    No permits shall be required for the following: 
A.  Excavation for building construction purposes pursuant to a duly issued building permit; 
B.  Excavation, removal or filling of an individual lot or single family home building site by a home owner; 
C.  Where the moving, grading or leveling of material is carried on by the landowner for the immediate use or development of the land upon which these substances are found; provided, however, that where sand, gravel, topsoil or other substances are removed from the site where found to another site of different ownership that a permit under these regulations will be required. A building permit shall be required for any construction activity to be carried on at the site. 
(Ord. 85 § 4.01, 1971) 
8.16.040 - Preliminary application and determination. 
A.  The owner of land upon whose premises it is proposed to construct a landfill shall submit an application, prepared in accordance with the following requirement, to the city for determination of the acceptability of proposed location. The application shall include a legal description of the land owned by the applicant within which the proposed fill site is located, with a statement of the type of ownership possessed by the applicant, a scale drawing showing the outline of the area on which filling is proposed, with sufficient landmarks to enable the city to identify the proposed fill area on the ground, a description of the type of landfill proposed, and a statement of the intended use of the area after completion of the fill. The city will thereupon examine the proposed site and determine whether it is suitable. 
B.  Should the applicant propose the actual construction and operation of the landfill to be conducted by a party other than himself, any permit which the city may subsequently issue will issue to the landowner and proposed operator jointly and will embody the joint and several obligations of each in accordance with these regulations. 
(Ord. 85 § 4.02, 1971) 
8.16.050 - Information-Supplied by applicant. 
    If the city finds the site to be suitable for the construction of a landfill, within the intent of this chapter, the applicant shall submit to the city the following information, which shall be prepared and signed by a competent registered professional engineer: 
A.  A map at a scale not smaller than one hundred feet to one inch on which there shall be shown: 
1.  The outline of the proposed fill area, identified on a rectangular coordinate system referred to the most convenient exterior section line and section corner or quarter section corner, 
2.  All boundaries of the property which are located closer than six hundred feet from any part of the fill area, 
3.  Areas from which cover material will be obtained, 
4.  Existing surface elevations of fill area, borrow areas, and of contiguous areas whose future utility will be directly influenced by the fill and/or borrow, shown by accurate contours at intervals not exceeding two feet. Elevations shall be expressed, directly, on U.S.C & G.S. datum, 
5.  Location of proposed access road from public highway to the fill area, 
6.  Drainage channels or other provisions to be made for drafting surface runoff from the fill area during construction and after completion of fill, 
7.  Location of employee facilities; 
B.  A similar map showing, by contours as previously specified, the surface elevations and slopes which will be established when fill and borrow operations are complete; 
C.  If any waste material, other than earth, is to be included in the landfill there shall be submitted a comprehensive statement describing the source and type of materials proposed to be placed in fill, together with plans showing the complete design of fill, including the following details: 
1.  Typical sections of fill, 
2.  Depth of layers, 
3.  Height of lifts, 
4.  Thickness of cover, 
5.  Number of lifts, 
6.  Surface slopes of lifts and final surface, 
7.  Direction of filling progress; 
D.  If the fill area is subsequently to be included in a plat or subdivision of land contemplating erection of buildings for any purpose, the maps referred to in subsections (A) and (B) of this section shall show the proposed subdivision layout; and the future locations of streets, building sites, and utility easements shall be clearly excluded from fill with any material other than earth. Such subdivision layout need not be shown in final exact detailed dimensions; however, if significant latitude is retained for future alteration of layout, the areas restricted to earth fill only shall be expanded accordingly. 
E.  Where waste material other than earth is to be included in the landfill there shall be submitted a report of a competent professional investigation and determination of the highest ground water level which can be expected in the fill area. The report shall indicate whether the ground water may have connection with an aquifer constituting a source of water supply and, if lowering of the ground water level by drainage is contemplated, shall indicate whether the proposed drainage would be likely to adversely affect any water supply. 
(Ord. 85 § 4.02*, 1971) 
* Ord. 85 contained two sections numbered 4.02. 
Article III. - Design 

8.16.060 - Filling on floodplains prohibited. 
    No landfill shall be permitted which will encroach upon the flood area of any drain or stream. 
(Ord. 85 § 5.01, 1971) 
8.16.070 - Earth fills. 
    Where a landfill will consist of earth only, the design of fill shall provide for the stripping of all areas where the total depth of fill will be less than six feet, so that the earth fill will be placed upon bare earth. In areas where the depth of fill will exceed six feet, all trees, vegetation and other materials whose consistency, shape or decomposition might cause significant settlement, shall be removed in advance of filling. Excepting in locations where the future use of the area is such that settlement will be of no consequence, earth fills shall be controlled so that the completed fill shall be compacted throughout to a density not less than ninety percent of the maximum unit weight of the earth material. 
    Unless otherwise specifically permitted by the city, all fill placed in water in existing ponds or pits shall be granular material which will be compact when placed in water. 
    Excepting in situations covered in the last preceding paragraph, drainage of earth fills, during and after construction, shall be maintained in such manner that fill shall not be placed in pond water, nor earth be washed from the fill into natural water courses nor onto the property of others. 
(Ord. 85 § 5.02, 1971) 
Article IV. - Fees and Deposits 

8.16.080 - Fees. 
    Fees payable to the city for review of landfill plans and inspection of landfill operations shall be as follows: 
A.  For examination of site and determination of suitability ..... $175.00 
B.  For review of plans for landfill consisting of earth only per acre of fill area ..... $10.00 
C.  For inspection of construction of earth land-fill for each month in which fill construction occurs ..... $50.00 
(Ord. 85 § 6.01, 1971) 
8.16.090 - Deposits. 
    Deposits shall be made with the city as follows: 
 To ensure payment of inspection fees and completion of fill in accordance with approved plans and these regulations, for landfills consisting of earth only, per acre of proposed fill area ..... $100.00 
With a minimum of ..... $1,000.00 
(Ord. 85 § 6.02, 1971) 
8.16.100 - Payment. 
A.  Fees for examination of proposed sites shall be paid with initial applications. 
B.  Fees for review of plans shall be paid with submission of plans. 
C.  Deposits as required in this section shall be paid before permits for approved fill will be issued. 
D.  Inspection charges will be billed and shall be paid monthly. 
(Ord. 85 § 6.03, 1971) 
Article V. - Permits 

8.16.110 - Issuance and renewal. 
    Permits for landfills will be issued for periods of one year. Permits will be renewable, without additional charge therefor, if: 
A.  Reasonable progress has been made in the construction of landfill; 
B.  Operation of the landfill has conformed to the approved plans and these regulations; and 
C.  Inspection charges have been paid when due. 
(Ord. 85 § 7.01, 1971) 
8.16.120 - Refusal of renewal. 
    Renewal of permits may be refused if: 
A.  Filling operations are inactive or conducted on so small a scale that, in the opinion of the city, the duration of filling operation will itself constitute a nuisance; or 
B.  Operation of the fill develops any unforeseen nuisance or hazard to the health or safety of the community, and adequate measures are not put into effect, forthwith, to correct such conditions. 
(Ord. 85 § 7.02, 1971) 
8.16.130 - Cancellation. 
    Permits will be subject to summary cancellation, and filling must stop, if: 
A.  Operations are in violation of the approved plans or these regulations; or 
B.  Unpaid inspection charges shall accumulate to such an amount that in the opinion of the city the balance of deposit may not be sufficient to guarantee satisfactory completion of fill in event of its neglect by the permit holder. 
(Ord. 85 § 7.03, 1971) 
Article VI. - Operations 

8.16.140 - Hauling 
A.  The hauling of landfill materials shall be confined to routes which shall be approved by the city and included in provision of permit. The city reserves the right, from time to time, in its discretion, to make revisions in approved routes. 
B.  Vehicles hauling landfill materials shall not be overloaded so that materials are spilled upon the highway. 
C.  On-site access roads shall be maintained, and if necessary, vehicle wheels shall be cleaned before leaving the fill premises, so that dirt and mud will not be tracked onto the highways. 
(Ord. 85 § 8.01 (part), 1971) 
8.16.150 - Hours of operation. 
    Landfills which are so located and operated that noises of operation can reasonably be considered disturbing to neighboring residents shall not carry on operations between the hours of eight p.m. and seven a.m., nor on Sundays or holidays. Other reasonable restrictions on hours of operation may be included in or added to the conditions of individual permits. 
(Ord. 85 § 8.01 (part), 1971) 
8.16.160 - City right of entry. 
    The officers and agents of the city shall have at all times the right of entry to any premises where any city landfill permit is in effect. 
(Ord. 85 § 8.01 (part), 1971) 
8.16.170 - Dust control. 
    Suitable control measures shall be used to prevent dust becoming a problem or nuisance, both at the fill and on access roads. 
(Ord. 85 § 8.01 (part), 1971) 
8.16.180 - Winter operations. 
    In winter operation snow and ice shall be removed before any earth cover is placed and spread on the fill. A supply of unfrozen earth cover material shall be maintained available, either in protected stock piles or in a natural bank protected from or not subject to freezing. Frozen cover material shall not be placed on the fill. 
(Ord. 85 § 8.01 (part), 1971) 
8.16.190 - Completion of landfill. 
    Within one year after the completion of the placement and grading of final cover on any landfill the area shall be dressed with topsoil and shall be seeded with a hardy, tough grass which will serve as a binder of the cover and eliminate problems of erosion and dust. This requirement may be waived by the city if the use of the area after completion of the fill includes other measures which will accomplish the same purposes. 
(Ord. 85 § 9.0, 1971) 
8.16.200 - "As-built" plan. 
    On completion of a landfill the permit holder shall supply to the city an "as-built" engineering plan which shall show by accurate survey data and references the actual location, depth, and final surface elevations of all areas containing fill. This plan shall be to the same scale and referred to the same control lines and datum as the plan submitted with the application for permit. The as-built plan submitted shall be an original tracing, in ink on cloth, or an original or acceptable reproduction made on a permanent transparent film. 
    The as-built plan shall be retained in the city files for reference in the consideration of developments which may subsequently be proposed on or adjacent to the fill area. 
(Ord. 85 § 10.0, 1971) 
8.16.210 - Work by city. 
    If the permit holder for any landfill fails or neglects to do any of the things required by the permit or these regulations, and he fails to remedy such omissions forthwith after notice thereof delivered to him or to his supervisor or the fill, or if neither the permit holder or fill supervisor can be readily located, the city shall have the right to enter on the property and to do by its own forces or its agents whatever may be necessary to eliminate any dangerous or objectionable conditions. The permit holder shall be billed and shall pay for all such work done by the city. 
(Ord. 85 § 11.0, 1971) 
Article VII. - Use and Refund of Deposit 

8.16.220 - Collection of unpaid charges. 
    The city may withdraw such amounts as required from the deposit on hand and apply the same to any inspection charges or charges for work done by the city. If such charges remain unpaid sixty days after billing, they are mailed to the record address of the permit holder. 
(Ord. 85 § 12.01, 1971) 
8.16.230 - Reduction of deposit. 
    On completion or discontinuation of any landfill, if in the judgment of the city the amount of deposit on hand is more than sufficient to ensure the performance of any further actions required of the permit holder, the city may reduce the amount of deposit to such sum as the city considers appropriate and sufficient and any additional amount of deposit on hand may be refunded to the permit holder. 
(Ord. 85 § 12.02, 1971) 
8.16.240 - Final disposition of deposit. 
    The balance of the deposit held on account of any landfill of earth only will be refunded when the fill has been completed or terminated and finished off to the satisfaction of the city and all amounts owed the city on account of the landfill have been paid. 
(Ord. 85 § 12.03, 1971) 
Article VIII. - Enforcement 

8.16.250 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety days or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court, together with the costs of the prosecution. 
(Ord. 85 § 12.04, 1971) 
Chapter 8.20 - OPEN BURNING 
Sections: 

8.20.010 - Findings. 
    The city finds the burning of leaves and other yard waste to be a matter of public health concern. The burning of these materials results in the production of air pollution which is laden with suspended particles, and the emission of a known carcinogenic agent (benzo a pyrene) and mold spores, which are known to aggravate hay fever and allergies and cause respiratory distress. The city finds that these deleterious effects can be mitigated by the prohibition of leaf and yard waste burning. The regulation of this activity has been deemed to be in the interest of the preservation of public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. 150 § 1.01, 1989) 
8.20.020 - Burning prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall permit or engage in the act of burning of leaves or other yard waste (such as woody and vine growth, vegetation and paper products) within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 150 § 2.01, 1989) 
8.20.030 - Enforcement. 
A.  The Wixom police department is authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  The enforcement duties authorized by this agreement shall include, among others, the following: 
1.  Investigation of ordinance violations; 
2.  Serving notices of violations; 
3.  Serving appearance tickets as authorized under Chapter IV or Public Act 175 of 1927, as amended, and Public Act 366 of 1984; 
4.  Appearance in court or other judicial proceedings to assist in the prosecution of ordinance violators; and 
5.  Such other ordinance enforcement duties as may be designated by the city manager. 
(Ord. 150 § 3.01, 1989) 
8.20.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars or imprisoned for a period not to exceed ninety days or both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. 150 § 4.01, 1989) 
Chapter 8.24 - OUTDOOR ASSEMBLIES 
Sections: 
Article I. - In General 
Article II. - Application 
Article III. - License 
Article IV. - Enforcement 
Article I. - In General 

8.24.010 - Findings. 
    The city council finds and declares that the interests of the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens require the regulation licensing and control of assemblages of large numbers of people in excess of those normally drawing upon the health, sanitation, fire, police, transportation, utility and other public services regularly provided in the city. 
(Ord. 82 § 1, 1970) 
8.24.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
    "Attendant" means any person who obtains admission to an outdoor assembly by the payment of money or by the rendering of services in lieu of the payment of money for admission. 
    "Licensee" means any person to whom a license is issued pursuant to this chapter. 
    "Outdoor assembly," hereinafter referred to as "assembly," means any event, attended by more than one thousand attendants, all or any part of which includes a theatrical exhibition, public show, display, entertainment, amusement or other exhibition, including, but not limited to, musical festivals, rock festivals, peace festivals or similar gatherings, but does not mean (1) an event which is conducted or sponsored by a governmental unit or agency on publicly owned land or property; or (2) an event which is conducted or sponsored by any entity qualifying for tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, being 26 U.S.C. s 501(c)(3) as incorporated by reference in Section 201 of the Michigan Income Tax Act of 1967, Act 281 of the Public Acts of 1967, being Section 206.201 of the Compiled Laws of 1948; or (3) an event held entirely within the confines of a permanently enclosed and covered structure. 
    "Person" means any natural person, partnership, corporation, association or organization. 
    "Sponsor" means any person who organizes, promotes, conducts or causes to be conducted an outdoor assembly. 
(Ord. 82 § 2, 1970) 
8.24.030 - License required. 
    A person shall not sponsor, operate, maintain, conduct or promote an outdoor assembly in the city unless he has first made application for, and obtained, as prescribed in this chapter, a license for each such assembly. 
(Ord. 82 § 3, 1970) 
Article II. - Application 

8.24.040 - Application for license. 
    Application for a license to conduct an outdoor assembly in the city must be made in writing on such forms and in such manner as prescribed by the city clerk and shall be made at least sixty days prior to date of the proposed assembly. Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars and shall include at least the following: 
A.  The name, age, residence and mailing address of the person making the application (Where the person making the application is a partnership, corporation or other association, this information shall be provided for all partners, officer and directors or members. Where the person is a corporation, a copy of the articles of incorporation shall be filed, and the names and addresses shall be provided of all shareholders having financial interest greater than five hundred dollars.); 
B.  A statement of the kind, character and type of proposed assembly; 
C.  The address, legal description and proof of ownership of the site at which the proposed assembly is to be conducted. Where ownership is not vested in the prospective licensee, he shall submit an affidavit from the owner indicating his consent to the use of the site for the proposed assembly; 
D.  The date or dates and hours during which the proposed assembly is to be conducted; 
E.  An estimate of the maximum number of attendants expected at the assembly for each day it is conducted and a detailed explanation of the evidence of admission which will be used and of the sequential numbering or other method which will be used for accounting purposes. 
(Ord. 82 § 4, 1970) 
8.24.050 - Required information. 
    Each application shall be accompanied by a detailed explanation, including drawings and diagrams where applicable, of the prospective licensee's plans to provide for the following: 
A.  Police and fire protection; 
B.  Food and water supply and facilities; 
C.  Health and sanitation facilities; 
D.  Medical facilities and services, including emergency vehicles and equipment; 
E.  Vehicle access and parking facilities; 
F.  Camping and trailer facilities; 
G.  Illumination facilities; 
H.  Communications facilities; 
I.  Noise control and abatement; 
J.  Facilities for clean-up and waste disposal; 
K.  Insurance and bonding arrangements. 
    In addition, the application shall be accompanied by a map or maps of the overall site of the proposed assembly. 
(Ord. 82 § 5, 1970) 
8.24.060 - Requirements for processing. 
    In processing an application, the council shall, at a minimum, require the following: 
A.  Security Personnel. The licensee shall employ at his own expenses such security personnel as are necessary and sufficient to provide for the adequate security and protection of the maximum number of attendants at the assembly and for the preservation of order and protection of property in an around the site of the assembly. No license shall be issued unless the chief law enforcement officer for the city, in cooperation with the director of state police, is satisfied that such necessary and sufficient security personnel will be provided by the licensee for the duration of the assembly. 
B.  Water Facilities. The licensee shall provide potable water, sufficient in quantity and pressure to ensure proper operation of all water-using facilities under conditions of peak demand. Such water shall be supplied from a public water system, if available, and if not available, then from a source constructed, located and approved in accordance with Act 294, Public Acts of 1965, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable state or local law, or from a source and delivered and stored in a manner approved by the city health officer. 
C.  Restroom Facilities. The licensee shall provide separate enclosed flush-type water closets as defined in Act 266, Public Acts of 1929, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto and in accordance with any other applicable state or local law. If such flush-type facilities are not available, the city health officer may permit the use of other facilities which are in compliance with Act 273, Public Acts of 1939, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable state or local law. 
    The licensee shall provide lavatory and drinking water facilities constructed, installed and maintained in accordance with Act 266 of the Public Acts of 1929, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable state or local law. All lavatories shall be provided with hot and cold water and soap and paper towels. 
    The number and type of facilities required shall be determined on the basis of the number of attendants, in the following manner: 
Facilities Male Female Toilets 1:300 1:200 Urinals 1:100 Lavatories 1:200 1:200 Drinking Fountains 1:500 Taps or Faucets 1:500  
    Where the assembly is to continue for more than twelve hours, the licensee shall provide shower facilities on the basis of the number of attendants, in the following manner: 
Facilities Male Female Shower Heads 1:100 1:100  
    All facilities shall be installed, connected and maintained free from obstructions, leaks and defects and shall at all times be in operable condition as determined by the city health officer. 
D.  Food Service. If food service is made available on the premises, it shall be delivered only through concessions licensed and operated in accordance with the provisions of Act 269, Public Acts of 1968, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable state or local law. 
    It the assembly is distant from food service establishments open to the public, the licensee shall make such food services available on the premises as will adequately feed the attendants. 
E.  Medical Facilities. If the assembly is not readily and quickly accessible to adequate existing medical facilities, the licensee shall be required to provide such facilities on the premises of the assembly. The kind, location, staff strength, medical and other supplies and equipment of such facilities shall be as prescribed by the city health officer. 
F.  Liquid Waste Disposal. The licensee shall provide for liquid waste disposal in accordance with all rules and regulations pertaining thereto established by the city health officer. If such rules and regulations are not available or if they are inadequate, the liquid waste disposal shall be in accordance with the United States Public Health Service Publication No. 526, entitled "Manual of Septic Tank Practice." If liquid waste retention and disposal is dependent upon pumpers and haulers, they shall be licensed in accordance with Act 243, Public Acts of 1951, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable state or local law, and, prior to issuance of any license, the licensee shall provide the city health officer with a true copy of an executed agreement in force and effect with a licensed pumper or hauler, which agreement will ensure proper, effective and frequent removal of liquid waste from the premises so as to neither create nor cause a nuisance or menace to the public health. 
G.  Solid Waste Disposal. The licensee shall provide for solid waste storage on, and removal from the premises. Storage shall be in approved, covered, fly-tight and rodent-proof containers, provided in sufficient quantity to accommodate the number of attendants. Prior to issuance of any license, the licensee shall provide the city health officer with a true copy of an executed agreement in force and effect with a licensed refuse collector, which agreement will ensure proper, effective and frequent removal of solid waste from the premises so as to neither create nor cause a nuisance or menace to the public health. 
    The licensee shall implement effective control measures to minimize the presence of rodents, flies, roaches and other vermin on the premises. Poisonous materials, such as insecticides or rodenticides, shall not be used in any way so as to contaminate food, equipment, or otherwise constitute a hazard to the public health. Solid waste containing food waste shall be stored so as to be inaccessible to vermin. The premises shall be kept in such condition as to prevent the harborage or feeding of vermin. 
H.  Public Bathing Beaches. The licensee shall provide or make available or accessible public bathing beaches only in accordance with Act 218, Public Acts of 1967, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable provision of state or local law. 
I.  Public Swimming Pools. The licensee shall provide or make available public swimming pools only in accordance with Act 230, Public Acts of 1966, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable provision of state or local law. 
J.  Access and Traffic Control. The licensee shall provide for ingress to and egress from the premises so as to ensure the orderly flow of traffic onto and off of the premises. Access to the premises shall be from a highway road which is a part of the county system of highways or which is a highway maintained by the state. Traffic lanes and other space shall be provided, designated and kept open for access by ambulance, fire equipment, helicopter and other emergency vehicles. Prior to the issuance of a license, the director of the department of state police and the director of the department of state highways must approve the licensee's plan for access and traffic control. 
K.  Parking. The licensee shall provide a parking area sufficient to accommodate all motor vehicles but in no case shall he provide less than one automobile space for every four attendants. 
L.  Camping and Trailer Parking. A licensee who permits attendants to remain on the premises between the hours of two a.m. and six a.m. shall provide for camping and trailer parking and facilities in accordance with Act 171, Public Acts of 1970, and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and in accordance with any other applicable provision of state or local law. While Act 171 does not become effective until January 1st, 1971, for purposes of this chapter, its provisions shall be effective and applicable upon the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
M.  Illumination. The licensee shall provide electrical illumination of all occupied areas sufficient to ensure the safety and comfort of all attendants. The licensee's lighting plan shall be approved by the police chief. 
N.  Insurance. Before issuance of a license, the licensee shall obtain public liability insurance with limits of not less than one hundred thousand dollars/three hundred thousand dollars (select appropriate figure) and property damage insurance with a limit of not less than twenty-five thousand dollars (select appropriate figure) from a company or companies approved by the state commissioner of insurance, which insurance shall insure liability for death or injury to persons or damage to property which may result from the conduct of the assembly or conduct incident thereto and which insurance shall remain in full force and effect in the specified amounts for the duration of the license. The evidence of insurance shall include an endorsement to the effect that the insurance company shall notify the city clerk in writing at least ten days before the expiration or cancellation of said insurance. 
O.  Bonding. Before the issuance of a license the licensee shall obtain, from a corporate bonding company authorized to do business in Michigan, a corporate surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars, fifty thousand dollars, one hundred thousand dollars, or select appropriate figure in a form to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned upon the licensee's faithful compliance with all of the terms and provisions of this chapter and all applicable provisions of state of local law, and which shall indemnify the city, its agents, officers, and employees and the council against any and all loss, injury or damage whatsoever arising out of or in any way connected with the assembly and which shall indemnify the owners of property adjoining the assembly site for any costs attributable to cleaning up and/or removing debris, trash or other waste resultant from the assembly. 
P.  Fire Protection. The licensee shall, at his own expense, take adequate steps as determined by the state fire marshal, to ensure fire protection. 
Q.  Sound-producing Equipment. Sound- producing equipment, including but not limited to public address systems, radios, phonographs, musical instruments and other recording devices, shall not be operated on the premises of the assembly so as to be unreasonably loud or raucous, or so as to be a nuisance or disturbance to the peace and tranquility of the citizens of Wixom. 
R.  Fencing. The licensee shall erect a fence completely enclosing the site, of sufficient height and strength as will preclude persons in excess of the maximum permissible attendants from gaining access and which will have sufficient gates properly located so as to provide ready and safe ingress and egress. 
S.  Communications. The licensee shall provide public telephone equipment for general use on the basis of at least one unit for each one thousand attendants. 
T.  Miscellaneous. Prior to the issuance of license, the council may impose any other condition(s) reasonably calculated to protect the health, safety, welfare and property of attendants or of citizens. 
(Ord. 82 § 10, 1970) 
8.24.070 - Review by city officials. 
    On receipt by the clerk, copies of the application shall be forwarded to the chief law enforcement and health officer for the city, the state fire marshal, and to such other appropriate public officials as the clerk deems necessary. Such officers and officials shall review and investigate matters relevant to the application and within twenty days of receipt thereof shall report their findings and recommendations to the council. 
(Ord. 82 § 6, 1970) 
8.24.080 - Time limit after filing. 
    Within thirty days of the filing of the application, the council shall issue, set conditions prerequisite to the issuance of, or deny a license. The council may require that adequate security or insurance be provided before a license is issued. Where conditions are imposed as prerequisite to the issuance of a license, or where a license is denied, within five days of such action, notice thereof must be mailed to the applicant by certified mail and, in the case of denial the reasons therefor shall be stated in the notice. 
(Ord. 82 § 7, 1970) 
Article III. - License 

8.24.090 - Contents-Posting. 
    A license shall specify the name and address of the licensee, the kind and location of the assembly, the maximum number of attendants permissible, the duration of the license and any other conditions imposed pursuant to this chapter. It shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon the premises of the assembly and shall not be transferred to any other person or location. 
(Ord. 82 § 9, 1970) 
8.24.100 - Denial. 
    A license may be denied if: 
A.  The applicant fails to comply with any or all requirements of this chapter, or with any or all conditions imposed pursuant to this chapter, or with any other applicable provision of state or local law; or 
B.  The applicant has knowingly made a false, misleading or fraudulent statement in the application or in any supporting document. 
(Ord. 82 § 8, 1970) 
8.24.110 - Revocation. 
    The council may revoke a license whenever the licensee, his employee or agent fails, neglects or refuses to fully comply with any and all provisions and requirements set forth herein or with any and all provisions and requirement set forth in this chapter or with any and all provisions, regulations, ordinances, statutes or other laws incorporated in this chapter by reference. 
(Ord. 82 § 11, 1970) 
Article IV. - Enforcement 

8.24.120 - Violation-Penalty. 
    It is unlawful for a licensee, his employee or agent to knowingly: 
A.  Advertise, promote or sell tickets to, conduct or operate an assembly without first obtaining a license as provided in this chapter; 
B.  Conduct or operate an assembly in such a manner as to create a public or private nuisance;C.Conduct or permit, within the assembly, any obscene display, exhibition, show, play, entertainment or amusement; 
D.  Permit any person on the premises to cause or create a disturbance in, around, or near the assembly by obscene or disorderly conduct; 
E.  Permit any person to unlawfully consume, sell or possess intoxicating liquor while on the premises; 
F.  Permit any person to unlawfully use, sell or possess any narcotics, narcotic drugs, drugs or other substances as defined in Act 343, Public Acts of 1952. 
    Any of the violations enumerated in this section is a separate offense, is a nuisance per se immediately enjoinable in the circuit courts, and is punishable by imprisonment in the county jail for not more than ninety days or by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
    It is further provided that any of the above violations is a sufficient basis for revocation of the license and for the immediate enjoining in the circuit court of the assembly. 
(Ord. 82 § 12, 1970) 
Chapter 8.28 - MUNICIPAL COST RECOVERY 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Findings and purpose. 
    The city of Wixom finds that a significant and continuous potential exists for extraordinary response situations based upon prior events which have taken place in the city, including those involving specialized response resources, that have and will continue to place a substantial financial and operational burden upon police protection services, fire protection services, emergency medical services, public works services, and other municipal services. The city finds that this chapter is necessary to protect the city from excessive expense resulting from the utilization of city resources in response to defined extraordinary situations and to fairly allocate the costs resulting from incidents among those responsible for them. The city further finds that the use of municipal personnel for certain responses interferes with the provision of routine and necessary public services to the residents of the city. The city has also determined that in traffic accidents involving drivers who are operating under the influence there is a greater likelihood of personal injury and property damage. The city finally finds that this chapter is necessary to authorize the imposition of charges and to establish a policy and set forth the methods by which the city will recover actual costs incurred in making extraordinary responses and providing services in connection with the same. 
(Ord. 08-02 § 1, 2008) 
8.28.020 - Definitions. 
    The following terms, phrases, words, and their derivatives shall have the meaning given herein, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    "Accident, including natural disaster," means an unforeseen or unexpected happening or occurring which of itself causes great harm or damage, or which creates the potential for great harm or damage to individuals and/or property, and which requires immediate and prudent securing and monitoring by the city and/or agents of the city, to reduce the potential for such damage, but not including an extraordinary response.
